 I know this has been explained a few times, but I would like to try to make the answer more clear. The example of a disease that wipes out large numbers of a population is a bad example of how mutations and natural selection occur. Since a species is living currently, it would be very unlikely that a mutation immediately occurs which is necessary for the survival of that species. When a deadly disease strikes a population, if only one or two members of the population have a mutation to prevent that disease, the population would die out. More than likely, the mutation occurred long ago and was unnoticed; it could certainly be as common as white rabbit hair vs brown rabbit hair. When the disease strikes, a significant portion of the population would need to have that mutation already in their genes in order for the species to survive, and because of this, the gene pool would still be large.
 
 More common is a mutation which offers a slight advantage, as explained by others here. In this case, the animal with the slightly beneficial mutation breeds with another animal without the mutation, then some children get the mutation and they breed with other animals. The animals with the fewest beneficial genetic mutations are killed off by predators, starve to death, etc. The animals with the most beneficial genetic mutations are most likely to survive and reproduce, and eventually the beneficial genetic mutations become very common across a species.
 
 It should also not be a good idea to assume that mutations were uncommon, for although most genetic mutations are uncommon in humans, there are a few that we see repeatedly. It would not be a far leap to assume that earlier species did not have the same protection from mutations that today's species have.

 One tip on "first cause" or "creator of the universe":
 
 For me, if you say " infinity going forward had to have a first cause", the next question is "what caused the first cause?" And you can keep asking that (infinite regress).
 
 So believing there is a first cause OTHER than the universe itself (like god or allah, etc.) doesn't really help clear anything up, at least for me. It just opens the door for the same question again and again. Does that make sense?
 
 For example:
 
 Tom: The universe seems to exist, perhaps it always has and always will, and was it's own first cause.
 
 Harry: Nonsense, it had to be created, to have a beginning. God created the universe.
 
 Tom: But who then, created god?
 
 Harry: God is the first cause.
 
 Tom: Why can't we just say the universe is the first cause, then we don't have to complicate things with a god?
 
 Harry: You're right, that makes no sense! ;0

I can't help but feel that one of the problems with our getting to grips with the history of the universe is our own experience of reality.
 
 We live lives that have stages- beginning, middle and end. Our day to day activities are underpinned by similar concepts- for example we get up, go to work come home, go to bed. Start to finish.
 
 Perhaps we need to free our minds of these underpinnings if we are to understand the universe- maybe it does not have a beginning and an end at all- just because it is our experience of life and applicable to many things we observe does not automatically make it a framework that the universe should operate within.
